REVISED STRUCTURE OF EDUCATION


Paper Misc. 3 of 1979


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [27th March, 1979].

    "That this House having noted the Report on the Ministry of Education, 1978, contained in Paper Misc. 3 of 1979,

    (1) supports the revised structure of education which will allow each pupil to study at a pace suited to his learning capacity and which will make him as bilingual as he can be,

    (2) approves flexibility in implementation particularly to accommodate the wishes of parents,

    (3) recommends periodic adjustments and changes to the revised structure which experience and advice of principals and teachers show to be desirable in the long term interests of pupils.". - (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education)

    Question again proposed.

2.31 p.m.

     Dr Lau Teik Soon (Serangoon Gardens): Mr Speaker, Sir, the education policy of our country must take into consideration the following goals. Firstly, the need to promote the indigenous languages: secondly, the need to prepare our young citizens for employment, and thirdly, the need to promote a strong foundation for good citizenry. There are, of course, other factors to be considered but I believe any education policy must achieve these three primary goals.

    Singapore is a multi-lingual and multi-racial society with the Chinese comprising 76% of the population, Malays 15%, Indians and Pakistanis 7% and the Eurasians and others 2%. The Chinese and Indian communities are not homogeneous. The Chinese are divided into the various dialect groups, such as the Cantonese, Hokkien, Teochew, Hainanese, Hakka and Foochow; the Indians into Telegu, Malayalam, Punjabi, Hindi and Bengali. Thus, it is not possible to impose any indigenous language as a common language in our country.

    Further, in view of our historical and political circumstances, we have evolved a language policy based on bilingualism, i.e. English as the link or common language and the mother-tongue as the cultural language. The adoption of English as the link language is a pragmatic one because it is a neutral language and it is the language of official, bureaucratic, commercial and ordinary interchange. It is also an international language.

    The language policy is, of course, tied up with the question of moral education and the capacity of the children to absorb two languages which, in the case of the Chinese and the Indian communities, means two foreign languages. Thus, for the Chinese child, English and Mandarin are two foreign languages, and for a non-Tamil speaking child, English and Tamil or Malay or Mandarin are the foreign languages. So it is a difficult task for the child to become equally proficient in two languages. In most cases, therefore, a choice has to be made, either more of one and less of the other or just to

Column: 84

concentrate on one with a minimum acquisition of the other language.

    The capability of the student to absorb the languages may be equated with their capacity to absorb knowledge. That is, the intelligent child may be expected to be more efficient in two languages than the less intelligent child. This may not necessarily be true in all cases but it can be accepted as a general guideline. Thus, what it means is that in the schools, streaming of children on the basis of language proficiency is necessary.

    On the question of moral education, there is no doubt that we want to build a modern society based on the relevant cultural values of our Asian traditions and those relevant ones from the West. No doubt through the inculcation of certain values of Confucianism, Hinduism, Islam and Christianity, we will build up men and women of sound character and a cohesive society in Singapore.

    Thus, I support the major recommendations of the Dr Goh Report. The need to restructure the primary and secondary schools, in accordance with the capabilities of the children to absorb language and knowledge, is a step in the right direction. However, there are certain problems of implementation which I would like to point out.

    As far as the language requirement for the various streams is concerned, I wonder whether the above average children would be able to compete with the brilliant children in the special bilingual stream, for example, at the pre-University level. According to the recommendation, the brilliant children will aftain equal proficiency in both languages while the above average children in the normal bilingual stream will attain a lower proficiency in the second language. While both categories may pass the GCE 'O' level, the question is whether those in the normal streams will be able to compete equally with those in the special stream at the Advanced level. Parents must be assured that their children who may be less proficient in the second language but do well in the other subjects should be given equal opportunity

Column: 85

for further studies, for example, admission into the University.

    One point with regard to the problem of teaching the second language should be noted here. This is the teaching of Tamil as a second language. Members may be aware that the learning of Tamil in many schools is not available to the students. Moreover, many of the Tamil teachers are relief teachers. The Ministry should, therefore, try to fill the gap as quickly as possible. The point is that the teaching of the second language, be it Chinese, Malay or Tamil, should be made available to the children in accordance with the choice of the parents.

    With regard to the streaming of children, I agree that the children should be streamed. But I wonder how this will be done. Will children be streamed and sent to different schools or will different streams of children be stationed in one school? I suggest that all the children be accommodated in one school. Firstly, the transfer of children, which is allowed for in the Report, can be done more easily if the children are in the same school. This transfer, however, is in the nature of upward and downward mobility rather than lateral. Thus, for example, if the various streams are in one school, then the top few in the normal stream can be moved upwards into the special stream, while the last few of the special stream can be moved downwards into the normal stream. The promotion or demotion in such a way will cause the least problem of adjustment to the children affected as the difference between them and their new classmates is minimal. Secondly, the streaming of children into different schools on the basis of language proficiency may result in racial segregation of our children. This is not desirable in our multi-racial society. Moreover, if all these children are in one school, there is intermingling of children of various races, intelligence and of various background. This, of course, is a desirable development towards a cohesive society. The sense of community will grow as each group will show concern for each other in the process of their daily contacts with one

Column: 86

another. Thirdly, and this is the point made by the Member for Anson yesterday, the streaming of brilliant and average children into super and normal schools inherently creates the stigma on the normal school children; that somehow the school and its students belong to an inferior category of human beings. This distinction between the elite untouchables, that is, those in the super schools and the inferior beings will be removed if all children are streamed within the same school.

    According to the Report, the top students or the 8% of the PSLE passes are expected to complete their GCE in four years and to do the two languages at first language level. Here I would like to add my reservations. Firstly, these children should not be overloaded with work and, secondly, they should be allowed to fall back to the lower stream if parents so choose. I am sure that parents are concerned with the increasing workload that the children have to do. They are tied up with continual assessment. Children are preoccupied day in and day out, with preparations for their monthly tests. They have hardly enough time left to do extra reading on subjects that may interest them. I would suggest that the monthly tests be abolished and that only the semestral examinations be retained. This relieves the pressure from the children as well as from the parents who are concerned with their children getting good results. At this point, it may be useful to state that children should enjoy their education and that they do not go through their school life merely, memorising fact after fact. A child may be top in the class, but it may mean that he is only good at memory work. It does not mean that he has been fully educated or that he has an all-round education.

    The Report stated that the moral education taught through Education for Living (EFL) in primary schools and civics courses in secondary schools should be abolished. In its place, it has been suggested that moral values should be inculcated through the story-method. I note that the main content of moral education is on traditional cultural values and that these

Column: 87

stories will mainly be ancient stories from the East.

    I wonder whether moral education should not be extended to education in citizenship. It is sometimes sad to note that Singaporeans are growing up without any knowledge whatsoever of their historical, social, cultural, economic and political development. The struggles of our leaders during the periods of crises, how they overcame them, the moral fibre and character of these men, the danger they faced and the consequences that would have befallen us if they had failed, are lessons to be taught to our children. In the process, such values as dedication to the community, personal sacrifice, hard work, courage, farsightedness and wisdom of our leaders will be passed on to our children.

    So I hope that while the roadside libraries where Chinese story books are available is a source for our moral education programme, that the National Library and the University of Singapore Library, where materials of the exploits of our national leaders are available, will also be another source for the writers on moral education.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, as the Hon. Prime Minister has stated, the teachers are the anchormen in moral education and the school has a vital role to play. But I believe that moral education - education in character building, habits of thought and behaviour, healthy mind and body, sense of loyalty and patriotism - is the responsibility of not only the school teachers but also the parents and the media-men, i.e. those involved in public communications and entertainment. Therefore, moral education must be a coordinated exercise; otherwise, the good values taught in school can be quickly undermined by agencies outside the school. In this respect, I am happy to note that the Committee of Parliamentarians studying the issue of Moral Education is headed by the Minister for Communications and Acting Minister for Culture. Moral education is as much the concern of every other Minister as it is of the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education.

Column: 88



    Moral education is supposed to provide the cultural ballast for our society, which is being urbanized and modernized. The Report mentions the risk of deculturisation but it has not touched on the danger of westernization. As an open society, we face the danger of becoming too westernized. The continuous presence of westerners in our society and the commercial pursuit to cater to their needs invariably increase the western cultural content in our society. The proliferation of various entertainment places, especially the nightclubs, and the import of western films for the cinemas manifest this trend. These places reflect to a considerable extent the cultural values, attitudes and modes of behaviour of the western society: some good, some bad. Hence, we have to put certain constraints on these places. Nevertheless, the danger of exposure of our school children, youths and other citizens to the selfish, permissive and hedonistic values of the West must not be overlooked by the Ministers.

    In this connection, Sir, I wonder whether any Ministry has bungled by allowing the symbol of the American permissive society and counter-culture to exist in our midst. I refer to the impending establishment of the Playboy Club in Singapore. Does this mean that we are prepared to tolerate the Playboy philosophy?

     Mr Seah Mui Kok (Bukit Ho Swee): Playgirl later on!

     Dr Lau Teik Soon: Are we prepared to see Singapore girls being turned into Playboy bunnies? We banned the Playboy magazine, yet we allow the Playboy Club to operate here. Where is the logic?

    Mr Speaker, Sir, what I have just said is pertinent to the issue of moral education. We cannot have double standards, one for the foreigners and the rich, and one for the rest of the citizens. In any case, Singapore is a small state, and no one can be isolated from development taking place in any part of it.

    Whether we like it or not, our children are exposed to such western cultural influence.

Column: 89

They are not only exposed to the entertainment places and the cinemas, they are also exposed to western influence at home via the television and radio. To completely resist the absorption of such cultural traits from the West is impossible; we are increasingly becoming westernized. The way we dress, the songs and dances we perform and the expression in thought and action in our relations with parents, relatives and friends certainly reflect an increase in westernization. But it is the good features of western society that we want to incorporate in the Singapore society: we have to reject the undesirable ones.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, one major reason why the Report has come about is that there is a need to reorganize the whole administration of the Ministry of Education. Policy guidelines may be spelt out in broad terms but it is up to the administrators to interpret them and implement them in detail. There is no doubt that the major contributing factor for the failure of our education policy was the calibre of our officials in the Ministry, particularly in the Schools Division. Many Members in this House and I have on previous occasions mentioned that certain officials in the Schools Division were responsible for aggravating the low morale of teachers and causing anxiety and discomfort in the schools. We wondered whether they were educationists or insensible minor tyrants. Now, the Report confirms what we had said. The Report mentions that, "it is sometimes difficult to make sense of what they (Schools Division officials) are trying to do." This is an astonishing conclusion to make, especially about people who are supposed to be the professionals. If the officials who are there now still cannot discern what they should properly do, I suggest that it will make more sense if the Schools Division is completely done away with.

    I hope that in the process of the reorganization, the responsibilities of the Ministry officials and the principals can be clearly delineated. This is a matter, Mr Speaker, Sir, that the Hon. Deputy Prime

Column: 90

Minister has answered during the Budget debate. I would like, however, to reiterate that the Ministry officials must confine themselves to overall administration of the education policy, provision of the physical facilities, curriculum development and supervision of the principals. However, there should be little interference by Ministry officials in the work of the teachers.

    What I would like to suggest, Sir, is that the principals together with the vice-principals and senior assistants be given full responsibility for the running of the schools. The principal's major concern should be the implementation of the curricula and the teachers should be left to work out the schedule of work for the whole year under the supervision of the principal. As far as teaching techniques are concerned, it should be left to the individual teacher. After all, the teachers are all trained teachers. Many of them are graduates from the Institute of Education and if they do not know how to teach, they should not have been given the certificate or diploma in the first place. If their teaching technique is bad, then the fault lies with the Institute of Education. What this means is that the Ministry officials should only deal with the principals and the principals with the teachers. Such a line of authority extends not only to the implementation of the curricula but also to the career development of the teachers.

    Of course, such a proposal may lend itself to abuse but teachers can always refer any complaint to either the Ministry or the Singapore Teachers' Union. In this respect, I would like to propose the abolition of an obnoxious unit in the Ministry called the Complaints Unit. It is surprising for me to learn that Ministry officials should have nothing better to do than to spend valuable time in investigating complaints by parents who send in anonymous letters. In future, such complaints should be channelled to the principals. Instead, the Ministry should consider setting up a Teachers' Liaison Centre or Unit, to which teachers can refer their views, comments and complaints to the Ministry officials. This would be in line with

Column: 91

what I had suggested sometime ago, namely, Meet-the-Teacher sessions at the Ministry.

    The key to the success of the education policy is, of course, the teachers. I think much has been said about the need to raise the morale of teachers. This can be done if the image and status of the teachers can be enhanced. According to a Hindu saying - I shall not be speaking in Tamil, Sir, this is the English translation - the person who teaches you to read and write is next to God. I am sure that in all other traditions, the teacher is held in such high regard. So may I suggest that the Minister pay more attention to this problem. In his Report, he has suggested that this is not a major problem. But some doubts have been cast over the credibility of the study team's finding. This is the point that the Member for Kolam Ayer raised yesterday. The survey was based on a very brief minute sample, namely, of 140 teachers and they represent only 0.7% of the teaching profession of about 20,000 teachers. If I may say so, Sir, many teachers who were interviewed by officials and particularly by members of the Study Team did not know the significance of the interviews or might not be prepared to speak up. The sad thing about the teaching profession is that many teachers have adopted the static positions of the three monkeys; hear nothing, see nothing, say nothing. So many of them complain but few are prepared to come forward to register their grievances.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in the Report one area of education seems to have been omitted, namely, the education of the educationally sub-normal or ESN children. For the ESN children, I wonder whether the Ministry will build a school for this category of children. There are many children who have failed many times in the normal schools and this may be due to a variety of factors. I hope the Ministry will look into this.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, education is a very complex issue and I would think that this is not the last report that we would see. We are an evolving society, constantly adjusting to changes. Likewise, the education policy will have to undergo adjustments. This, of course,

Column: 92

is implicit in the Minister's recommendation that certain flexibility and freedom be allowed to the Ministry in the implementation of the policy.

    One of the major complaints of teachers and parents alike has been that they have not been consulted or informed about the many changes in our education policy. There has been no communication or there has been a communication breakdown between Ministry officials, principals, teachers and parents. The impact of any education policy is long standing. It can only be felt after a few years and if there have been errors, it would be very difficult to remedy them. Thus, it would be useful to discuss certain changes with teachers and parents, whose children have to bear the consequences of good or bad education policy. I would, therefore, suggest in this connection that, firstly, the Ministry should embark on a five-year plan for education, indicating what developments would take place, how they have to be implemented and at what cost. This plan should be reviewed at the mid-term in order to assess the success and failure of it. There should be little, if any, change during the five-year period. Secondly, the parent-teacher association (PTA) in schools should be activated and expanded. At present, the schools' advisory committees and management committees as well as the parent-teacher associations are nothing more than fund-raising agencies. It may be useful for the PTA to discuss some of these problems and give their views on the education policy. Thus, it would have been helpful if the Dr Goh Report had been studied by the PTA and other advisory committees of the school.

    Further, the Report can be studied by the Education Sub-Committee of the Citizens' Consultative Committee. I am pleased to note that certain Members of Parliament have discussed the Report with their CCC members. If I may, Sir, I would like to place on record that a group of CCC members in my constituency held a meeting with me last Sunday to air their views and comments on the Report and on various other aspects of our educational system. It was a useful and beneficial exercise; in fact, I have taken into

Column: 93

consideration their views and comments during this debate.

    In conclusion, Mr Speaker, Sir, may I reiterate that I have no objection to the Motion standing in the name of the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education. It is full of promise of a better future for our children. I, therefore, support the Motion wholeheartedly.

    Thank you, Mr Speaker, Sir.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Fong Sip Chee): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are two amendments standing in my name. The hon. Members for Anson, Moulmein and Jurong have so enriched the House by their in-depth observations yesterday, and their timely chord of warning on the misgivings they have on the revised structure should suffice to enlighten the luminaries (they are all here) in the Ministry of Education. The Deputy Prime Minister himself has also further elaborated on the new structure. Their exercises have rendered the first amendment* unnecessary and I, therefore, do not propose to proceed with it. I shall, however, discuss the rationale behind which the amendment was originally moved.
* The amendment, standing in the name of Mr Fong Sip Chee, reads as follows:

    "To leave out sub-paragraph (1) in lines 3 to 5 and there to insert -

    '(1) supports the revised structure of education based on a system common to all pupils which will make them as bilingual as they can be, and at the same time allow those with the capability to study at an accelerated pace suited to their capacity.'.".


    Sir, I now beg to move.

    "At end, to add a comma and the following new subparagraph -

    (4) resolves that the Minister of Education do report to Parliament after 2 or 3 years on the progress, unresolved problems and state of implementation of the revised structure of education'.".

    Sir, today's sitting of Parliament is especially convened for the sole purpose of debating the findings of the Education Study Team presented in Parliament as a Report on the Ministry of Education, 1978. The Prime Minister, in his letter to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education has aptly

Column: 94

described the publication of the Team's findings and the exchange of letters "a watershed in our history. A generation of Singaporeans is coming of age."

    No better conclusion can be drawn than the Prime Minister's remarks. Never before has a more critical report on our education system and objectives been placed before the scrutiny of the entire nation. Views in support and criticisms were freely expressed, and MPs' guts were challenged even before they speak their minds. The Lim Tay Boh Report dealt with the exigency of a different era, when political consideration took preference over everything. Hence, its watered-down implementation.

    In a way, the Report now before the House vindicated hon. Members' criticisms in this House over the years on the education system in Singapore. Not a few Members proffered their comments, some with pungency, including mine. In the process, a few Members emerged languid and flayed; others, who were less fortunate, were scarred by the retorts by the Front Benchers, but nevertheless fought on. To those who have their pride injured, I respect them for their courage and sincerity. They will find satisfaction in the Report which, in fact, is a precis of their comments. They were duty-bound to bring to the attention of this House the effects and defects encumbered in the present system. To the Prime Minister, we acknowledge his continuous concern for the education of our young. We are grateful for his serious and forthright manner in which he dealt with us as he did with this most sensitive subject.

    However, it is impossible to incorporate all the views of each and every hon. Member. If we do, the final product will be an utopian system or a frankenstein.

    We are here to seek concord on how best the revised structured of education can be

Column: 95

implemented. And concord we will achieve. Criticisms in the past have been many, and hon. Members would do well not to re-amplify them or bemoan too much the state of the past. It serves no useful purpose. What is important now is whether we have the courage to accept the challenges ahead to ensure that the new structure will bear the desired fruit.

    The Report, in a nutshell, lists out the deficiency of the system which our pupils have been subjected for many years. Indeed, as responsible Members of Parliament, we should now lend support to rectifying these defects and try to give life to the recommendations.

    Not a single decision on education in the past had been made without the inhibitions of political considerations and cultural constraints. Discussions in the House were confined mainly to the physical aspects of the various systems and their administrative shortcomings. If hon. Members' views were found to be wanting in wisdom and practical considerations, it was because they exercised judicious care in refraining to test the sensitivity of the subject.

    Hon. Members are aware of the many meetings amongst MPs on the subject of education. The discussions were frank, and frequently vigorous, if not more critical, than those hitherto expressed in this House. I myself have suffered cuts and bruises in the many exchanges I had with the Prime Minister. My fate of being knocked down every time was almost predictable! Fortunately, I have so far been able to survive the mandatory counts. Some well-intentioned colleagues advised me that I should have instead counted 10 before I ventured my views! Otherwise, the next time it will be a T.K.O.

    Times have changed. Singaporeans today are an entirely different breed from those in the fifties and early sixties. We are now able to scan a farther horizon, and politically matured to be able to tackle the problem more objectively without the inherent fear of the prejudices of language and culture.

Column: 96



    A major political decision has been made. It is up to us to give it the blood and muscle and determination to see it through its implementation, Parliament's endorsement and hon. Members' commitment are sought for this purpose - a decision today will ensure the quality of our next generation on whom the fortunes of our nation will be entrusted.

    Cultural and other traditional prejudices must now be set aside in the matter of survival of Singapore as a nation. I say this, and say so categorically as a Chinese educated. This is a bold statement which I realise may cause untold damage to my political standing if made in the early sixties. Indeed unthinkable, in the fifties, as the Member for Anson has said. I do so without fear only because I am confident that our people will understand the priorities of survival before anything and everything. Education is a life-long and continuous process. May I quote a Chinese saying: bai nian shu ren (    ). There are enough idioms in the Chinese language to describe education, the teachers and the pupils.

    Hon. Members are all agreed that there is no such thing as a perfect system in education. We have never hoped to ever evolve one in the first place. (The Minister for Home Affairs may wish to know that the hon. Member for Serangoon Gardens has taken over my role by his eloquent exposition on Tamil education). The consideration is simply that of meeting the realities, however painful they may be.

    When I visited the Federal Republic of Germany many years ago, I found to my surprise that education was a Landers' responsibility. "Landers" means the state's responsibility - quite similar to the cantons in Switzerland which the Deputy Prime Minister described yesterday. There was no common system in the Federation. Dissatisfaction was evident, even among the high intellectuals and the intelligentsia, indeed even very explicit disillusion over the education system there. But to my question as to why the Federal Republic of Germany was able and has been able to produce the high quality of technocrats and literary

Column: 97

personalities, in spite of the defects they so vehemently criticised, a high official was quite dumbfounded. I still do not have the answer today, but it was quite a revelation to me. The reason that we have been able to progress so far to what we are today, under the much criticised defective system, must have been due to the sheer determination of our people, their ballast and the ever-present urge to do well. All these virtues are inherent in our cultures. In short, it was a defective system made workable, at least by those who have the tenacity to battle through the highly competitive arena. High attrition rate is the natural consequence in this system.

    This, of course, is no consolation, and neither do I attempt to exonerate the Ministry of Education and their luminaries for their past misdeeds. What I intend to highlight is that there is that great virtue in our people which has been oblivious to us and taken for granted lightly. In essence, it is the quality of the people that finally decides - a quality which we can exploit to our full advantage and which the new Restructured System must take cognisance of.

    With due respect to the Japanese, they are said to be poor linguists! They even boldly advertise their linguistic handicap in nearly every other instruction pamphlet which accompanies their products. But hon. Members should take note: the important thing is that they sell, and the whole world buys their products all the same! And little do we realise that such display of linguistic handicap can be so misleading! It is fair to say that the Japanese progress through the English language. For every latest literature on Science and Technology published in English, the Japanese will produce, in remarkably short time, the translation or their version of it and quickly pass down to their technocrats and technicians. Here is a case of knowledge gained through a foreign language and quickly exploited. This has been possible only because they can progress hand-in-hand with the western world, and in many instances, even overtaking the western industrialised countries

Column: 98

without at the same time losing their identity and the verve and vibrancy of their hard culture. It is a case of happy and balanced blending of the two seemingly opposing factors.

    The Japanese have found the solution. But we have an edged advantage over the Japanese. In our case, English language has been with us and in our system for the last 150 years. It is not a strange language to us. This is our edge.

    It must be remembered, nevertheless, that even if all of us speak the English language like an Oxon, like the Attorney-General, Mr Tan Boon Teik, there is no English culture here to back up the language. There is no afternoon tea. Some of the gentlemen have been described by the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education as Westernised Oriental Gentlemen (WOG). They may have afternoon tea. There are no bowler hats and no pudding! Ironically, while there is no English culture to back the English language, the Chinese culture is here, but the language suffers an evident decline. Even Tamil. Fortunately, not Malay as yet. When we have more Chinese, Malays and Tamils speaking English, the cultural values of the communities should not be allowed to subside and eventually fade out. It is in this respect that the fear of deculturalisation is so real that it does not escape the attention of the Study Team.

    Language teaching is the most difficult of all subjects. The language teacher has to impart not only the meaning - frequently multiple meanings of a word - but also its different usage, the idioms and phrases, the metaphors and the simile. Unlike technical subjects where formulae and equations serve as the basis for solving problems, where H2O means water and nothing else, and where theorems provide proven basis for assumptions.

    Second language teaching is even more demanding. The teacher has to correlate, interpose and transpose two different languages. If a teacher can really master the effective command of the two languages, he hardly waits to get out of the teaching

Column: 99

service! His difficulty is further compounded by a number of other factors, such as reading materials, text-books, pressure from parents and Ministry headquarters, and the pupils' prejudice and fear of the language itself. All these notwithstanding, it is not impossible to evolve a syllabus for second language teaching, particularly the Chinese Language, which is not a phonetic language, can be learnt without tears. Second language teachers are hard to come by in the first place, even more difficult to train. The teacher himself must first possess linguistic ability.

    Yet the streaming of students is based on linguistic performance! So far, I have not come across any literature on the correlationship between linguistic ability and the innate ability or quality of a person. I will leave this for the experts to ponder. In the meanwhile, streaming must be executed meticulously. If a flair for language or linguistic ability is the criterion to determine a person's intelligence, several hon. Members here, including the Frontbenchers, should not be in this House.

    Moral teaching is one aspect which has not been accorded its rightful place in the old curriculum. A child is taught the final axiom, and told of the discipline and ethics expected of him. He is not told and, therefore, not able to retain the reasons behind the tenets which have been forcibly implanted into his mind. He does not know why he has to behave or think in a certain manner. He does not benefit from stories or historical anecdotes associated with the final principles he has to remember. But, remember he will, only for as long as the examinations last! It is to fill this semi-vacuum that the Team's proposal on formal instruction on moral education is most welcome. I understand that the syllabus will be drawn up by a Special Committee formed recently under the chairmanship of the Minister for Communications and Acting Minister for Culture, and to whom I have sent a few sample materials.

    On the question of the morale of teachers, the Study Team has identified a number of crucial factors affecting the morale of the teaching profession. Whilst it has been

Column: 100

observed that the low morale is more apparent than real, it is equally true that teachers have been a frustrated lot, and for too long a time! That they are able to continue to give of their best in spite of the heavy odds against them deserve our highest salute.

    The Study Team quite rightly noted the effects of criticisms by the press and the public on the morale of the teachers. I am afraid that some hon. Members here in this House have been equally guilty. Damaging statements were made both inside and outside the House. The Prime Minister once even made a remark to the effect that a man worth his salt and wanted to do well will not join the Teaching Service, in the event, those who remained were the Physical Education teachers - the brawn, he said, and the brains belong to their woman counterparts!

    A teacher's social status is what a community believes and accords him. In the Malay community, a teacher is always known as Che'gu at whatever social occasion, his recognition spreads across all strata of the community. He earns the high respect and esteem of the people he comes into contact with and even long after his retirement. He is Che'gu all his life. In the Indian community, the Guru is one from whom the masses seek moral and spiritual guidance.

    The Chinese have always placed high respect for teachers. He is known as Lao shi (    ) all his life, although this title in the present day is being used and confined only to his students. This is a Confucian maxim gradually giving way in direct proportion to the gain of the western idealistic liberalism. In an article I read many years ago in one of our local Chinese newspapers, I was amused by an article by a cynic who wrote about the greetings between a pupil and his teacher in three stages. In primary school, a child greets his teacher with a respectful "Sir". In secondary school, a plain and indifferent "Mister" and after leaving school or in the university, a spirited "Hi!".

    I suppose none of us today think it amusing. All factors impeding the revival of the good morale of the teachers must be

Column: 101

removed. This is of vital importance and if the revised structure of education is to succeed, the Team's recommendations as contained in paragraph 5 of Chapter 6 must be implemented with utmost urgency.

    A teacher is charged with the difficult yet all-important task of educating and moulding the young. He influences the students, he teaches them, guides them and prepares them for adulthood. His task is onerous and not even the examination results can quantify his contribution one way or the other. It is his intrinsic contribution that we must recognise and, therefore, the sooner the pay scale of the teaching profession is rationalised in the light of their well-earned recognition, the better they become effective digits as front-line educators. Of course, money is not the only solution. But how else can we show our respect and recognition to him in the reality of a materialistic society?

    Both the proposed primary and secondary structures place emphasis on downward streaming-off rather than upward creaming-off. This is the objectionable part of the otherwise excellent recommendations.

    The proposed revised structure of education, whilst taking cognisance of the defects in our hitherto diseased education system, is unfortunately still elitist in its spirit and content. Whilst the yardsticks for streaming, particularly at Primary 3 have not been proven to be absolutely reliable, I am prepared only to accept it in the absence of other known and tested methods relevant to our situation here in Singapore. What is the norm of the education system? Ten years, 11 years? Whom do we aim the system at?

    Education, whatever its system and objective, must be aimed at the average and that should be the norm. They form the majority. It must be an universal system. The revised structure is still stained with some past defects. It is an improvement with a provision that each pupil will be allowed "to study at a pace suited to his learning capacity." Nobody can quarrel with the principle that each pupil be allowed to study

Column: 102

at his own pace. It is a fair approach. A noble objective.

    It cannot be denied that it is again designed to cater for the minority of 12% to 14% who will make it to the GCE 'O' or 'A' level. It tries to be fair, but I fear it is politically disastrous. A child will be subjected to streaming at, say, Primary 3 under this system. The brighter ones will be allowed to continue in the normal stream whereas the slow or even average learners will have to take on another year. On the findings that about 12% to 14% will eventually make it to the 'A' level, the stigma will be attached to the majority of the 86% of pupils and parents. Nobody wants to be branded as dull. In this system, the whole family - father, mother, and children - are all branded as duffers at one go! Repugnant it must be to them, Sir, to say the least.

    The recommendations for the Primary School Education System as contained in paragraph 3.1.1.(a), (b) and (c) of Chapter 6, in spite of what I have said earlier, are perhaps, less offensive, when compared to the other system, since it caters for the majority of the 60% of the Primary 1 cohort passing the PSLE without having to repeat any year. The streaming-off of the remaining two categories, that is, 20% each under points 2 and 3 of paragraph 3.1.1.(b), is acceptable. This system takes into consideration the different learning capacity of pupils, and a slower pace of study may well salvage some of the materials who may be re-channelled into the extended bilingual stream at secondary school, although leapfrog promotion from the monolingual stream to the normal bilingual stream appears to be remote.

    The lateral movements among the three streams seem fair, and no pupil or parent can deny that the opportunity for reward for doing well in his later years has been entrenched in the system.

    In the Secondary Education System, three streams, or sub-streams or rather exigency streams, are proposed. They are:-

    (a) the Special Bilingual Stream for the top 8% of the Primary 1 cohort;

Column: 103



    (b) the Normal Bilingual Stream (4-year system) to cater for the 31% of the cohort, and

    (c) an Ordinary Stream leading to the CSE (Certificate of Secondary Education). I presume this is equivalent to the LCE. This is a 5-year course.

    I have always maintained that an education system must be applicable to all. All pupils must undergo the same system, say, a total of 11 years for the combined primary and secondary courses. There can still be streaming. But the emphasis should be on picking out the brighter ones and giving them, say, a double promotion, as proposed by the Member for Jurong yesterday, or be channelled to special classes with a special syllabus to accelerate their studies, while the remaining students will continue to pursue the normal stream. When I say "normal stream" here, it means a normal stream and not the normal stream as proposed in the recommendation of the Study Team. They have a different connotation there. The proposed streaming, if left unadjusted, can cause grievous harm to our next generation. I can imagine in future social gatherings and conversations, one may suffer the indignation of having to declare if one is the product of the normal (at present 10 years) course, the extended course, or the streamed-off (11 years) course. 86% of our population will have to live with the stigma attached to them for the rest of their lives. A common course under which everybody must go through, with the brighter ones enjoying the prospect of double promotion or creaming-off to special curriculum classes, is quite a different proposition. The difference between the two proposals is simply this. In the present elitist-orientated system, streaming is done at two stages - Primary and Secondary. The brighter ones are to continue. They gain nothing except that they pass the threshold. For the average and the slow learners, who by no means are beyond redemption, they take one year extra.

    In the alternative 11-year-common-to-all system, as I have proposed, streaming will mean that the course for the brighter ones will be accelerated by one year. It is a gain for

Column: 104

them, whilst the average and slow will continue with the normal course of 11 years at no loss of time, pride and confidence. After all, it means that it is just the other boy getting a double promotion. He has done well. So be it. Both types of courses can be conducted even at the same school. Otherwise, there will be a time when a certain school sparks, a certain school stinks, and some other schools sink!

    In a lateral movement, this can be done without much difficulty. It provides for the slow developer the ever-present challenge and opportunity to do well. As the proposed revised structure stands, provision is made for movement back into the main stream for those who pick up later.

    It may be argued by the Minister that the two proposals mean the same thing. Certainly it does to a great extent. But if we were to place the emphasis correctly, we will reward those who can cope (the 14%) instead of enraging the 86% by an indictment which they and their parents must naturally resent. I am not trying to split hairs.

    The sooner the proposal for a Certificate of Secondary Education (CSE) is implemented, the better the system will see a more permanent feature emerging. For the brighter students, they can sit for the CSE one year earlier and move on to GCE 'O' level. The recommendations, as contained in paragraph 3.1.2.(b) and (c) in Chapter 6, seem to exempt these cases from the need to sit for the CSE as proposed in paragraph 3.1.2.(d). The CSE seems to be especially designed only for those in the Ordinary Stream, but not those in the Special Bilingual Stream (3.1.2.(b)), or the Normal Bilingual Stream (3.1.2,(c)). But any pupil in these two latter streams who unfortunately fails his GCE examination will end up without even the CSE.

    This is what I mean when I say that the revised structure is aimed at the minority, though brighter pupils. Certainly, these pupils deserve special attention. We should not waste their time unnecessarily since they have the capacity to cope with the heavier lesson-load. But what about the rest? True,

Column: 105

they will be catered for under the other parallel streams, but why the obvious and deliberate running down of these pupils?

    Mr Speaker, Sir, we are here today to make a commitment to support a system of education so vital for our next generation. It is a commitment not to be taken lightly. It is a commitment for Singapore's future. It is a commitment which we cannot easily unscramble. It is for this reason that hon. Members have so exhausted their imagination and thoroughly searched their conscience in expounding their views yesterday, today and will do so in the next two days in this House. It is for the same reason that I, with your indulgence, the forgiveness of the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education and, of course, the tolerance of hon. Members of this House, propose to move the amendment to the Motion before the House. The need for this amendment is obvious. '.

Column: 106

the amendment proposed by the Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour. I am very glad that he has withdrawn his first amendment because I find it difficult to understand what he really wants, I think he assumes that every child goes to a secondary school and it is a matter of providing 10 or 11 years of education for the child. Actually this is not the case. A very large number of school children spend nine years in a primary school and they still do not pass the Primary School Leaving Examination.      The Minister for Health (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Mr Speaker, Sir, it has been a long time since the Government tabled a paper for debate in Parliament, and I am indeed pleased as this will give newcomers to Parliament an opportunity to participate in a debate of this kind.

    It is not just we in Singapore alone who are concerned about the state of education. If we require any consolation, we can examine the woes over education in Britain, the United States and other parts of the Western world. In fact, in October 1976, the British Prime Minister, Mr James Callaghan, joined in a public debate on the low standards of basic education in the United Kingdom; the

Column: 107

debate grew out of the failure of the government to overcome its economic crisis. The U.K. needed better educated people to help regenerate industry. What did they find? In the engineering industry, they found that apprentice recruits did not have an adequate grasp of the four operations of arithmetic - addition, subtraction, multiplication and division. The culprit was New Mathematics taught in the schools. New Mathematics was being directed at making students competent in computer language. Worse still, they discovered that at 'A' level, students with only 3Cs were studying engineering at a university, whereas better qualified students were studying medicine, arts and the social sciences. In fact, many of the engineering and technology courses in British universities and polytechnics would have closed today if vacant places had not been filled by overseas students. Higher School Certificate, or 'A' level education, bore no relation to the needs of an industrial trading state living off its manufacturing and commercial skills.

    In the United States, they have what is called the Scholastic Aptitude Test which is taken by students who wish to enter colleges and universities. Likewise, American parents were dumbfounded when they found that Johnny could not read or could not count. On reviewing Scholastic Aptitude Tests over the period 1963-75, they were astounded that there was a decline of 44 points in verbal ability and 30 points in mathematics. The drop in educational standards was attributed to New Mathematics again, television, plus a host of other factors beyond the control of the school.

    The Singapore education system is not as bad as it has been made to appear in the newspapers and through parental discontent with the failures of their children. In fact, the Singapore education system has moved in tandem with our economic policies since 1968 and has contributed in no small measure to our economic success today. But there are failures too in the education system. If there are failures, they are due to our own making. The first reason for the failure was the call to build "The Rugged

Column: 108

Society". The Minister of Education was then the Minister of Defence. As the Minister of Defence. he found that school leavers were skinny and bespectacled. He did not think they were potential recruits, either for the Army or the Police. So directives were given out to the Ministry of Education to step up extra-curricular activities and, as a carrot, points were given for ECA which would qualify students for admission into pre-university classes. This, of course, means that if a student spends more time on ECA, he is going to spend less time on studies and on home work.

    Let me relate to Members a personal experience. A mother came to see me about her daughter who was in a morning class in one of the girls' schools in Singapore. She was very worried for her daughter who was being retained in Secondary 2 for two years. She sought my advice. I found out that the daughter was participating in the Youth Festival year after year. And since she was a willing student, they made a donkey of her by making her run in inter-school sports races. Furthermore, she took part in other tournaments like basketball and ping pong. Although she left for school at six o'clock in the morning, she did not return till eight in the evening. That, of course, made the mother very worried indeed. The solution was simple. I advised her to cut out part of her extra-curricular activities and, in any case, she was not going to be recruited into the Army.

    As we gave the push to ECA - every school was competing for the title, "The Best School Band", or to win a Cup in inter-school competitions - the need for bilingualism was also emphasised at the same time. It began first with the secondary schools and later it was extended to primary schools. So we have two apposite objectives, the yin and yang. If we read Dr Goh's Report. we will find that he has honestly annotated the history of confusion sown among principals and teachers between the years 1966 and 1978 and when hardly a year passed without policy directives emanating from the Ministry. So it was not to be unexpected that the Ministry of Defence in the course of time discovered that

Column: 109

the rugged society was producing illiterate soldiers. So we have soldiers wearing different tags to indicate the dialects they speak.

    This Report might not have been written had not the failure to achieve bilingualism was shown in the high failure rates of 62% for PSLE and 66% for the GCE 'O' level examination over the years 1975 to 1977.

    The lesson is that educational policies must have priorities and they must be given time to mature. It is true that an egg requires incubation. But applying more heat to the egg will more likely kill the chicken in the eggshell than make it hatch faster. And that is exactly what has been happening to the Ministry of Education which has been receiving a lot of heat.

    What is implicit, of course, is that the existing heavy load on students must first be eased. Bilingualism and technical education, as the Minister of Education explained to Members yesterday, do make an impact on the well-being of our economy. But it also makes an impact in making our society more cohesive. ECA does not, and should be treated as part of the joys of childhood and adolescence, as I treated ECA during my childhood days.

    Switzerland has been publicised in our English newspapers as a model where bilingualism or multilingualism has succeeded. I am amazed that the Ministry of Education has picked this line from the newspapers or could it be that the Ministry of Education fed that line to the newspapers. Maybe Switzerland has succeeded because it does not have a Ministry of Education. But I can tell Members that its citizens are encouraged to participate in policy making by way of referenda. Multilingualism in Switzerland is based on French, German and Italian, but these are languages derived from Latin, having a common Roman alphabet and are phonetic. But spoken German in Switzerland is different from High German taught in the schools. It is a dialect peculiar to the northern part of Switzerland and cannot be under-

Column: 110

stood in the border states of Germany or Austria. What I need to emphasise is that what is taught in the schools need not necessarily be the lingua franca that is being used.

    English and Chinese have nothing in common. They are entirely two separate languages, one using phonograms and the other ideograms. Japanese is one language which uses Chinese characters or ideograms called kanji and phonograms called katakana and hiragana. Some persons suffer from defects in the nervous system and when they do so, they fail to understand the, meaning of the printed word. They suffer from what is called word blindness. The clinical term is alexia. A study of such neurological patients in Japan showed that surprisingly Japanese patients could read ideograms, i.e. they could read kanji. But, on the other hand, they could not comprehend the meaning of words formed from katakana or hiragana. This has given rise to the postulate that reading ideograms or learning the meaning of ideograms is through association of the visual cortex and the speech areas of the brain while reading words made up of phonograms is through association of the auditory cortex and the speech areas. So there exist two different systems in the brain for learning languages and because Japanese is a single language, these two systems reinforce one another. This is not so in the study of English and Chinese, each of which employs a different system and reinforcement is absent. It may explain why our attempts to push bilingualism in English and Chinese are meeting with so much difficulty and resistance.

    The Japanese obviously have the advantage. As Table 3.1 of the Report shows, the attrition rates at primary and secondary school levels are zero in Japan, zero and 9% in Taiwan, but 29% and 36% in Singapore. These differences are due mainly to the fact that in Japan and Taiwan one predominant language is taught, whereas in Singapore we are giving equal weightage to two different languages which do not reinforce each other.

    In promoting our policy of bilingualism in English and Chinese, we must recognise

Column: 111

inherent physiological systems for learning languages which may not be equally developed in every child.

    Bilingualism is possible provided we accept the fact that applying equal weightage in achievement of linguistic proficiency, particularly for English and Chinese, is false. It is an error and it cannot be applied to the majority of the student population. It is true that there are some with exceptional linguistic abilities and these students should be sent to an Institute of Languages, but they are the minority.

    English, with an alphabet, is easier to study than Chinese which does not have an alphabet. For English stream students, studying Chinese in our schools has been made unnecessarily difficult by the fact that up to-date the Ministry of Education has not listed out which are the first 1,000 active characters and which are the next 1,000 less active characters. The Director of Education told us that all we needed were 2,000 characters at PSLE level. He may believe it, but I am afraid his teachers in Chinese do not believe him at all. Far from it. They have impressed upon me very sternly and consistently that we need 5,000 characters at PSLE level and 10,000 characters at 'O' level. So I did a little mental arithmetic. supposing we are quite content with studying 2,000 Chinese characters, retaining them in our memory and be able to retrieve them and to write them, at primary school level for six years. It means that on the average the child would need to study 330 characters a year. When the child reaches Primary 3, and if the child has forgotten what he has done in Primary 1, then the number of characters that he will learn or acquire at the end of six years will probably be less than 2,000. That is quite a difficult task.

    Ideograms have to be memorised whereas phonograms only require to be spelt out, and spelling is far easier than memorising ideograms. You can form your own vocabulary. If you are a scientist and you have discovered a new substance or a phenomenon, you can give it a name. It will be published in international scientific

Column: 112

journals. If the Japanese discovers anything, they will publish the name in katakana, not in new Chinese ideograms. Language is one of the reasons why science and technology in China have not progressed as fast as science and technology have advanced in the West.

    The psychologist will tell you that there is such a phenomenon as interference existing in the brain. There is a mental block. So when you have to use both English and Chinese, it may be that one is not only not reinforcing the other, but one may cancel the other out. So it ends up with students who can be only monolingual. It is a fact that even Chinese students in English schools, who come from homes where father speaks Mandarin, mother is teaching Chinese in a Chinese school, describe Chinese as the most unpopular subject. They are falling between the English stool and the Chinese stool. So we need first to rectify this omission by the Ministry of Education. There is an urgency that the Ministry should set out its list of 2,000 fundamental characters or basic characters which the child will have to know at PSLE and 'O' levels. It can be done.

It examined 7,075 news releases and newspaper articles comprising nearly 7 million characters. Eventually 3,200 characters were compiled for further discussion and study. This would suggest that we do not need as many as 5,000 characters to study. A basic set of 2,000 characters will be quite appropriate in the context of Singapore. This is an important reason why bilingualism has turned out to be a failure.

    I would like to caution the Ministry of Education not to swing to an extreme position where bilingualism is considered preeminent. So that all officials in the Ministry concentrate on promoting bilingualism, regardless of the fact that students have

Column: 113

other aptitudes which can give them saleable skills when they leave school. If Lee Pan Hon's musical talent had not been spotted by chance, it is quite possible that he would be no more than an average student in Kreta Ayer and end up as a fiddler on the SAF Road Show.

    Furthermore, each faculty has its own specific requirements for studying special courses. Take the case of Medicine. Because rapid advances have been made in molecular biology, it is essential that students at 'A' level should have a firm grounding in Chemistry and Biology. So do not think too much of President's scholars who go abroad and come back with a First Class. For most students who do not come from wealthy homes this overseas route to university is remote. Although it was stated that the approach the Study Team took was that of the generalist, many people felt uncomfortable about the fact that all the Team members were very young, except, of course, the Chairman. Many, especially those in the educational circle, felt that it would be better if a few older and experienced educators were included in the Team, I did share their point of view. But after careful reading of the Report, I have to admit that the job could not have been done better even if some older and experienced educators were included in the team. However, that does not mean that I agree with everything that is said in the Report. I shall now give some of my comments.

    During the course of its study the Team consulted and interviewed altogether about 300 people. That, I think, is a good number. But one thing that disappoints me is that representatives of professional organisations, such as the Singapore Teachers Union, Singapore Chinese Middle School Teachers Association and a few others, were not interviewed. It happens that the presidents of two of these organisations are Members of

Column: 133

this House. I do not know how they felt; but if I were in their position, I certainly would feel hurt for not being consulted.

    My next comment concerns the section in Chapter 1 entitled "Nanyang University". It is very unfortunate that it has become a practice to associate the name "Nanyang University" with the problems of Chinese stream schools and the failure of bilingual education. The result is that people tend to be misled to think that it is because of Nanyang University that we now have problems with Chinese schools and bilingual education. Actually the situation is the other way round. The problems of Nanyang University are caused by the problems of Chinese schools and the failure of bilingual education. This section of the Report also contains some statements about Nanyang University which I would call incorrect or inaccurate. In fact, I think the contents of the section could be made clearer if references to Nanyang University were omitted.

    Under the section entitled "Moral Education" in Chapter 1, comments were made regarding courses in "Education for Living" and "Civics". I think these courses are not meant for the promotion of moral education but rather to teach the pupils some general knowledge. This knowledge could be quite important to the pupils, particularly those from poor family background. The suggestion that, to avoid deculturisation, pupils of each ethnic group be taught early history of their ancestors seems to be a little narrow-minded. I suppose a brief history of all ethnic groups should be taught to all pupils; and the content should not be limited only to early history. Anyway, details on what to teach the pupils will have to be taken care of by careful designing of the curriculum and syllabus.

    The Prime Minister expressed his surprise at the finding that when Mathematics and Science were taught in English in Chinese primary schools there was no improvement in English, instead there was a decline in the standard of Science, and, I suppose, of Mathematics also. This phenomenon has

Column: 134

actually been known for quite some time. Perhaps because of poor feedback, no one has ever ventured to tell the Ministry or, perhaps, the authority in the Ministry did not wish to hear it.

    Here, I would like to offer my simple explanation for the phenomenon. The English used in the teaching of Science and Mathematics, particularly the language used in the textbooks, is different from the English taught in the English classes both in respect of expression and vocabulary. The Science and Mathematics classes therefore do not supplement the study of English, and the extra language exposure time is then wasted. Furthermore, the English text in Science and Mathematics textbooks is usually more difficult than those in the English textbooks. As a consequence, the pupils do not understand the language in Science and Mathematics textbooks. Science and Mathematics happen to be subjects which require complete understanding to master. When taught in English, the Chinese school pupils could not understand and, therefore, they did not learn. In writing or adopting future textbooks, it is important to make sure that the language used in textbooks of the various subjects should not be more difficult than that of the language textbook. The curriculum must also be designed such that the content courses can supplement the language courses in the learning of languages.

    On the high attrition rate in our education system, I do not think it is fair or meaningful to compare it with that of other countries. Our attrition rates at various levels are set by the vacancies in secondary schools, 'A' level classes and tertiary institutions, and not according to performance of the pupils. Our real problem is, as aptly pointed out in the Report, low literacy and ineffective bilingualism. Perhaps we need to find out why.

    It is a well known fact that some schools are better than others in respect of academic performance of their pupils. I suppose the language proficiency of their pupils also runs parallel with their academic performance. It

Column: 135

is easier to understand why this is so with some secondary schools because they are usually more popular and prestigious and they usually admit pupils with better PSLE results. Variation in performance in primary schools is more difficult to understand. Home background of the pupils is, of course, one of the factors. The fact that government-aided schools are better than government schools is again well known. But what we need to know is whether this is due to the better home background of the pupils in the aided schools or to other factors, for instance, tradition, better teachers and principals. One possible factor is provided in the section of Chapter 6 of the Report entitled, "Morale of Teachers". Apparently, the morale of teachers is higher in the better schools. Therefore, the higher the morale of the teachers, the better the performance of the pupils. Or, is it the other way round?

    I am afraid I have to touch on the morale of teachers again. I agree with quite a few of the hon. Members that the morale of teachers is actually low. I think most teachers would not admit freely their low morale in the interviews, because such admission might have an adverse effect on their standing. According to the figures given, with 72% of the teachers not satisfied with their social status, 92% worrying about too many changes in education system, 80% complaining of no chance to air their grievances and 74% thinking that there is no chance for promotion, I just do not believe that only 18% of them have low morale.

    The defects in the existing education policies and systems are mentioned in Chapter 4. I agree with most of the findings.

    Chapter 5 is perhaps the best chapter in the Report. The various shortcomings of the Ministry's administration were identified and analysed. It must be a surprise to those who are not familiar with the Ministry of Education to know that there are so many problems in the Ministry. However, to many in the educational circle, the findings are not surprising at all. I have heard comments such as, "We know that all the time", "It has been like that all the time". And yet the whole

Column: 136

problem was exposed only after a study by the Team. That somehow reminds me of the story of the Emperor's new dress by Hans Christian Anderson. Let us hope that the major overhaul now going on will succeed so that the Ministry will be in a position to tackle the problems arising out of the proposed new education system.

    The suggested new education system, in which pupils are allowed to proceed at different speeds according to their abilities, is theoretically sound. The streaming of pupils into three categories with a possibility of lateral movement among the streams,is good design. However, the system is a very complex one and there are bound to be problems on implementation. Technical and administration difficulties will be overcome, I presume, in due course.

    The most difficult problem, I think, is the explanation of the system to the public and parents so that they can accept the system. Most people would agree on the advantages of streaming according to the abilities of the pupils. But any parent will be unhappy if his or her child is not classified as above average or average, and certainly will be extremely disappointed if the child is classified as poor. There will be a tremendous pressure on the pupils to drive towards better classification. I can imagine in future Members of Parliament will have to face long queues of parents asking for reclassification of their children in their Meet-the-People sessions.

    Another point not to be overlooked is the effect of classification on the pupils themselves. The psychological impact or suffering of being classified as belonging to the lowest grade is something which I believe no Member of this House has ever experienced. As a teacher for many years I have some experience through observation of my students. It is very frustrating, humiliating and sad to be classified as the lowest grade. Sometimes it may lead to insanity or suicide. The poor response and high dropout rate of the Basic Course in our schools are probably not due to the defects in the system but rather to the lack of confidence of the parents and their children after being classified as

Column: 137

such. Anyway, let us hope that parents as well as the children can be convinced that proper streaming is best for them.

    In the suggested system, the first streaming will be done after three years of primary schooling. I would expect pupils with better family background to do better as in the case of the PSLE examination. It is also suggested that the first three years of primary schooling will concentrate on language learning. I suppose it is not possible to teach the pupils nothing else but languages. Some mathematics, general knowledge, art and other subjects must also be taught. In order that pupils with poorer family background or poorer linguistic ability do not lose out, the "intelligence test" should be well planned and lateral movements between streams should be allowed, whenever possible or necessary.

    In the suggested secondary school system, streaming seems to be based entirely on teaching and learning of languages. I have to emphasise again that education is not just the learning of languages. A pupil who is good at two languages is not necessarily a brilliant one. He may be good at nothing else. On the other hand, one who is not good at the second language or even the first language can be good at other subjects. The L1, L2 and L3 levels in the various streams need not be fixed. For example, in the brilliant or good category, students with good linguistic ability can study CL1, or for that matter, ML1 or TL1, up to the present CL1 'O' level. Others who are not so good in languages can drop CL1 at Secondary 3 or Secondary 4 and concentrate on other subjects at Secondary 4 for the 'O' level examinations.

    One of the defects of the previous administration and system was the ineffectiveness of the feedback system. Very often, complaints and comments from schools, teachers or parents did not reach the Ministry or were not considered by the Ministry. On the other hand, schools, teachers and parents often did not

Column: 138

understand the policy and intention of the Ministry. Steps have to be taken to promote better dialogue between the two ends.

    Education is a complicated business. Even with good administration in the Ministry, good education system, good curriculum and syllabus, the importance of good schools cannot be over-emphasised. Of course, all the schools cannot be equally good and some difference in performance must be acceptable. However, schools with consistently poor performance need special attention. It is hoped that, with the new system, the control and supervision of schools will be effective so that all Singaporeans will be ensured of a good education for their children no matter to which school they send their children.

    Finally, Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to congratulate the Education Study Team on a job well done.
