     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Chin Harn Tong)( In Mandarin): Sir, since Singapore's independence and the subsequent political and economic development, our education policy has undergone several changes. Yet our basic educational objective has not changed. This basic objective is to cultivate in our students a sense of national awareness, to dispel the sense of being immigrants, to enable the students to master two languages, and to provide them with the ability to learn a particular skill in order to earn a living. However, the problem now lies in the fact that in the past ten-odd years we have attained considerable achievement in economic development. We have social stability and full employment. The people are adequately provided for. Our younger generation of citizens has grown up in a period of peace and prosperity. They have not experienced the various kinds of difficulty and poverty, and so they would not appreciate that the spirit of hardship experienced by our ancestors is the foundation stone on which we built our

Column: 139

prosperity which our nation enjoys today. Therefore, they tend to take everything for granted. Moreover, Singapore, being an international commercial centre, foreign influences are deeply felt. A distorted sense of values and inappropriate styles of life are exerting undue influences over our young citizens. They only know enjoyment and cannot withstand hardship. They care only for themselves and not for others. They become typically selfish people.

    Singapore is a young nation. The criteria for nation building have many limitations. We have to depend on the hard work of all the people and the peaceful co-existence of the various races in order to survive. Only in this way can the two million people be more cohesive and with this integration make a contribution to the progress of Singapore. Therefore, the wrong concept of values and inappropriate behaviour must be rectified. To attain this objective, it is undeniable that education plays a very important role.

    In this Report, we are very glad to note that moral education will occupy an important place in our future curriculum. The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education has also emphasised that we must instil the good Asian cultural traditions in our young students so that they may understand the reasons for living a humane life. I think we all agree on this point. The ultimate aim of our education policy is to build a generation of healthy citizens possessing not only a rich knowledge, but also good physiques, and most important of all, a good character and a proper sense of values. This will be reflected in their attitude towards hardship in life, in mutual assistance and understanding. In general, the emphasis of what our refined Asian cultural traditions should be is whether or not a person in society has accepted his social or moral responsibility.

    But how are we to instil in the minds of our youths an accurate sense of values? We feel that rather than emphasise on certain abstract concepts, would it not be better if we try to influence them by the introduction of descriptive stories of the life and strife of

Column: 140

model ancient people, their supreme devotion to society and country, their assistance to their friends and so on? This can be introduced to the students by narration in story-form. The students will surely be influenced by the great deeds and nobility of these heroic characters, and will adopt this spirit in their own way of life.

    Since our country has undergone great modernisation, and our economy still undergoing substantial development, there is all the more need to emphasise the importance of moral education. Our Prime Minister has stated in his letter to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education that one important question we are concerned with is how to improve the quality of our citizens. "We have to give our young basic common norms of social behaviour, social values, and moral precepts." There must be an accurate sense of values and a moral precept acceptable by oriental society.

    To achieve such an objective, we need a group of teachers who can become models of good citizens. As was pointed out by our Prime Minister, teachers are the guides for our moral and social spirit. The basic mission of teachers is not only to impart knowledge but also to cultivate the moral character of the students. However, in a highly commercialised society, it is not easy to find teachers with such quality. In order to promote a good moral education, we must, first of all, solve the problem of improving the quality of teachers.

    Sir, to achieve perfection in education is usually an ideal. However, we often encounter various problems and obstacles in implementing our education policy. For example, our bilingual education policy, which we have been promoting in the past two decades, has encountered many problems and obstacles. This has been frankly pointed out in Dr Goh's Report. We have taught "Education for Living" in our primary schools and "Civics" in our secondary schools all these years. However, since the text of the EFL is more of a preaching nature, we do not seem to have achieved any tangible result.

Column: 141



    To succeed in promoting moral education, we also need a set of textbooks capable of exerting a great influence, besides good teachers who can set good examples for our citizens. As our Prime Minister has pointed out, spreading the norms of social and moral behaviour is best done through stories, legends, myths and folk-lores so that the students will learn and accept the proper concept of human behaviour. Compiling textbooks of such a nature is also one of the important tasks indispensable to the promotion of moral education.

    Sir, this Education Report by Dr Goh is an important milestone in the development of our education for the future. We hope that the suggestions on moral education, like the streaming of students, will achieve the expected degree of success when they are implemented.

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng (Mountbatten): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, so long as the Hon. Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education does not accuse me of being out of context later on, I reserve my submission that the Goh Report would be more appropriately titled "Report on the Education System in Singapore" and not the "Report on the Ministry of Education 1978".

    Sir, if we accept that education is an enculteration process designed to help a child to acquire a desirable culture and make him become a useful and loyal citizen in society, then the Goh Report, together with the Hon. Prime Minister's response, forms just that pragmatic base to work upon.

    The introduction of the Goh Report to Parliament is indeed timely with the increasing trend of parents sending their children to English stream schools, and the increasingly strong influence of western norms by way of the TV and cinema and, without a balanced cultural norm of Asian origin, we may run the risk of perpetuating a depoliticised, self-centred and deculturalised set of citizenry for the future. This must never

Column: 142

ever happen because if it does, then all the good work that has been done to build Singapore into what it is today will slowly be eroded away.

    In order to prevent this from happening, we must instil into our school children a set of values in life that will help them to become loyal and useful people. This can be done partly by giving the child a key that he can use to unlock his cultural heritage, i.e., bilingualism. The English Language will in future become more or less the common language between racial groups. Ironically, from a cultural development point of view, the question to ask is, is it necessary to go through such expense recruiting English Language teachers from overseas? Language teaching has in a way, a close affinity to cultural development. Have we really exhausted our local talents? I would think not. With the amount of money that the Ministry is willing to pay, our local graduates may reconsider moving into the teaching profession. Many of these graduates have moved into commercial firms. I should think local graduates are more suitable.

    In the development of the child into a useful and educated citizen, I wonder why no mention has been made in the Goh Report on the development of the child right from the very word, "go". When a child is born, he is without culture or knowledge. Gradually, as he interacts with his environment, he begins to develop both mentally and culturally. There are many things taught at this age that will have a long-lasting effect on the child. The role of parents in the education of the child is of paramount importance. It is my belief that parental influence during the child's tender years can assist the child to raise his 10. I submit that the lack of parental support is a more relevant explanation of school dropouts than just environment of the home. If this is accepted, then RTS, especially in a small unique island like ours, can play a very important role in propagating this idea to the less educated parents in child-upbringing. The idea is that we will then be able to tap the best brains from our reservoir of human resource. What I am thinking of is a short programme, even if it

Column: 143

has to be repeated, on how parents can positively promote IQ levels and speech skills through active parental support of the child's learning process. You do not, for example, "goo-goo" to your child when he "goo-goos" at you. So says the Hon. Minister of Defence, Say, "how are you" or some other intelligible words.

    The pre-primary schools or the kindergartens can also play a very important part in the development of the child into a useful citizen. This aspect has not been mentioned in the Goh Report as well. As the child's mind at this stage is very malleable, it is very important to maximise good input not so much the textbook knowledge and also, I stress, very carefully done without force. In this case, kindergartens must be carefully supervised to ensure that a set of good values is inculcated at this early age. Furthermore, through properly supervised play activities, children can be taught to develop the habit of mass participation and, hence, group identity. By careful upbringing of the child the percentage pattern of the brilliant, the above average, average and below average might change. Not only will wastage be reduced but effective contribution by each individual will eventually be increased.

    The Goh recommendation for three subsystems of education, each of which is adjusted to the rate of learning of the child is indeed a sound recommendation. For the system to work, however, everybody involved, such as principals, teachers and parents including students, must understand the way the system works and that it is aimed primarily at allowing the child to develop at his own pace and become a useful citizen. It must be accepted that different children have different capacities to learn. But proper parental support and well-supervised kindergartens may help to improve the learning ability of each child (quite independent of the physical home environment) and hence increased contribution by each child in the future.

    In fact, I believe that the streaming of children into the various sub-systems would

Column: 144

form a rather sensitive area of the Goh Report in as far as parents and the school children are concerned. It will be all right for children who get streamed into the better streams but for those who get streamed into the poorer classes will form the unhappy lot of people. They may be the minority. The problem is, the child may be an intelligent child but because the input during his infancy was negligible or even nil except "goo-goos", then, through no fault of his own, his future may be sealed for ever. The question is: can any one way be devised in which assistance can be extended to these unfortunate people? True, it is difficult to have an ideal system where we can ensure that those who get streamed into the poor classes are confirmed poor performers. Surely, the mass media can do a lot here to assist. Programmes can be designed to encourage parents to bring their children to the various scenic and educational spots to expose their young to better inputs. It may sound elementary but it is important. Or programmes can be run to instruct parents on correct child-upbringing; or to have baby programmes - all designed towards giving the child the best and earliest input as possible.

    We must try to avoid the situation where the better-off gets better and the worse-off gets worse - like the rich getting richer and the poor getting poorer. The task is difficult, but the possibility of saving a few is there.

    For the other streams after the PSLE, teachers and principals must also pay utmost care when going about streaming students. Conscientious care must be taken to follow the child's progress and bring the child back to the better stream should the child show some signs of improvement. Although this is provided for in the Report, in practice this must happen. I submit that the teacher will be able to carry out her tasks more conscientiously with higher morale. In making this statement I am not accepting the findings of the task force in relation to teacher morale because the interviewing was not carried out 'blind'. One might be able though to draw the conclusion that the 18% of the 140 teachers who were interviewed

Column: 145

had slightly more guts or who were slightly more disenchanted than the others. I submit that questionnaires should have been sent out to probe teachers' morale but done anonymously. I believe the present system of promotion has done a lot to lower the morale of our teachers. It is an undignified system. Generally, the teachers' salary must be improved and with this done, teachers' status and morale should move upwards. But, I submit, not overnight. It will take time for things to settle but at least, this is a step in the right direction.

    I personally believe that, except for a few, most teachers are extremely keen to follow the progress of their students and encourage them along the way. Teachers take pride in the success of their students. Though they do not express their hearts in so many words, their feelings are there all right. Teachers are very often blamed for the poor performance of their students but it is high time they were encouraged along by parents and students as well.

    Finally, Sir, it is worthwhile mentioning that the system, like any other system in the past, must never be allowed to backfire in the sense that being designed to reduce pressure on students, some over-aspiring parents may push their children too hard to get into better streams that these children would eventually suffer even more.

    Parents must be encouraged by all means possible to take an active interest in the development of their children. They must also be encouraged to be practical enough to accept the verdict on their children's performance but they must also be encouraged to discuss their children's problems with the teachers concerned. In general, I submit that the Parent-Teacher

Column: 146

Association (PTA) does not seem to be very active in the schools that I know of. I feel that the problem here can be that parents of children who do well feel that they have no cause or purpose to meet the various teachers. On the other hand, parents of children who fail often shun the teachers probably because of communication problems; or because they are too busy earning their dollars: or they may not have heard of the existence of such an association. The end result is normally a gathering of a few outgoing parents who take the trouble to go to the schools to meet teachers and principals socially. Though this is good, the association does not achieve its overall objective.

    At this juncture, it is necessary for me to remind the principals to rethink on how to remotivate the Parent-Teacher Association as another tool to ensure the proper implementation and success of the Goh Report.
